fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Suppose that {\mathopen {}\llbracket R\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} is (a, b)\colon R\to A \times B. Then R(x,y) and R(x,y') may be respectively interpreted (up to isomorphism) as (a\rho _{1},b\rho _{1},\rho _{2}) and (a\rho _{1},\rho _{2},b\rho _{1}), where \rho _{1} and \rho _{2} are the product projections out of R \times B.

fr:embedded-tex.fr:embedded-tex-body: \DiagramSquare { width = 3cm, nw = {R \times B}, nw/style = pullback, ne = R, sw = {A \times B \times B}, se = {A \times B}, north = {\rho _{1}}, south = {(x, y)}, west = {(a\rho _{1},b\rho _{1},\rho _{2})}, west/style = {>->}, east = {(a,b)}, east/style = {>->} } \qquad \DiagramSquare { width = 4cm, nw = {R \times B}, nw/style = pullback, ne = R, sw = {A \times B \times B}, se = {A \times B}, north = {\rho _{1}}, south = {(x, y')}, west = {(a\rho _{1},\rho _{2},b\rho _{1})}, west/style = {>->}, east = {(a,b)}, east/style = {>->} }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Now, suppose that {\mathopen {}\llbracket R(x,y) \wedge R(x,y')\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} is (up to isomorphism) either composite of the following square.

fr:embedded-tex.fr:embedded-tex-body: \DiagramSquare { width = 4cm, nw = {R(x,y) \wedge R(x,y')}, nw/style = pullback, ne = {R \times B}, sw = {R \times B}, se = {A \times B \times B}, north = {(\gamma ',\beta ')}, south = {(a\rho _{1},b\rho _{1},\rho _{2})}, west = {(\gamma ,\beta )}, east = {(a\rho _{1},\rho _{2},b\rho _{1})} }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The first sequent demands that \gamma = \gamma ' and that \beta = \beta '. Suppose that au = av. Then (a\rho _{1},\rho _{2},b\rho _{1})(u,bv) = (au,bv,bu) = (a\rho _{1},b\rho _{1},\rho _{2})(v,bu). Thus, u = v.
Note that {\mathopen {}\llbracket x\colon A.\exists y\colon B.\mkern 5muR\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} is the image of a. This is an isomorphism by the second sequent. Thus, a is a cover.

Since a is a monic cover, it is an isomorphism. Thus, we can define f := ba^{-1}. Note that (a,b) is an equalizer of f\pi _{1} and \pi _{2}. Thus, the required sequent is satisfied. Suppose that g\colon A\to B also satisfies the required sequent. Then (a,b) is an equalizer of g\pi _{1} and \pi _{2}. Since (\mathsf {id},f) factors through (a,b) via a^{-1}, g\pi _{1}(\mathsf {id},f) = \pi _{2}(\mathsf {id},f). Then it follows that f = g.
Let \mathcal {C} be a regular category and R \in \mathsf {Sub}(A \times B) be a relation satisfying the following sequents:

fr:ul.fr:li: Functional: x\colon A, y\colon B, y'\colon B|R(x,y) \wedge R(x,y') \vdash y = y'

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Then there is a unique morphism f\colon A\to B in \mathcal {C} such that x\colon A,y\colon B|R \dashv \vdash f(x) = y is satisfied.

Suppose that {\mathopen {}\llbracket R\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} is (a, b)\colon R\to A \times B. Then R(x,y) and R(x,y') may be respectively interpreted (up to isomorphism) as (a\rho _{1},b\rho _{1},\rho _{2}) and (a\rho _{1},\rho _{2},b\rho _{1}), where \rho _{1} and \rho _{2} are the product projections out of R \times B.

fr:embedded-tex.fr:embedded-tex-body: \DiagramSquare { width = 3cm, nw = {R \times B}, nw/style = pullback, ne = R, sw = {A \times B \times B}, se = {A \times B}, north = {\rho _{1}}, south = {(x, y)}, west = {(a\rho _{1},b\rho _{1},\rho _{2})}, west/style = {>->}, east = {(a,b)}, east/style = {>->} } \qquad \DiagramSquare { width = 4cm, nw = {R \times B}, nw/style = pullback, ne = R, sw = {A \times B \times B}, se = {A \times B}, north = {\rho _{1}}, south = {(x, y')}, west = {(a\rho _{1},\rho _{2},b\rho _{1})}, west/style = {>->}, east = {(a,b)}, east/style = {>->} }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Now, suppose that {\mathopen {}\llbracket R(x,y) \wedge R(x,y')\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} is (up to isomorphism) either composite of the following square.

fr:embedded-tex.fr:embedded-tex-body: \DiagramSquare { width = 4cm, nw = {R(x,y) \wedge R(x,y')}, nw/style = pullback, ne = {R \times B}, sw = {R \times B}, se = {A \times B \times B}, north = {(\gamma ',\beta ')}, south = {(a\rho _{1},b\rho _{1},\rho _{2})}, west = {(\gamma ,\beta )}, east = {(a\rho _{1},\rho _{2},b\rho _{1})} }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The first sequent demands that \gamma = \gamma ' and that \beta = \beta '. Suppose that au = av. Then (a\rho _{1},\rho _{2},b\rho _{1})(u,bv) = (au,bv,bu) = (a\rho _{1},b\rho _{1},\rho _{2})(v,bu). Thus, u = v.
Note that {\mathopen {}\llbracket x\colon A.\exists y\colon B.\mkern 5muR\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} is the image of a. This is an isomorphism by the second sequent. Thus, a is a cover.

Since a is a monic cover, it is an isomorphism. Thus, we can define f := ba^{-1}. Note that (a,b) is an equalizer of f\pi _{1} and \pi _{2}. Thus, the required sequent is satisfied. Suppose that g\colon A\to B also satisfies the required sequent. Then (a,b) is an equalizer of g\pi _{1} and \pi _{2}. Since (\mathsf {id},f) factors through (a,b) via a^{-1}, g\pi _{1}(\mathsf {id},f) = \pi _{2}(\mathsf {id},f). Then it follows that f = g.
